Award.AwardTitle: Degenerations and Moduli in Algebraic Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports research in algebraic geometry, a central branch of mathematics. It aims to understand, both practically and conceptually, solutions of systems of polynomial equations in many variables. Algebraic geometry has important applications to other fields of mathematics, such as number theory, topology, and analysis, as well as to physics, biology, cryptography, and engineering. The particular questions under study in this research project involve moduli spaces, which are sets that parameterize solutions of geometric classification problems. Some of the topics under study originated in string theory in physics, and results of this work may in turn find application there. Graduate students are involved in the project.

The investigator will work on a range of questions in algebraic geometry centering on degenerations, compact moduli spaces of stable varieties and pairs, and connections to the minimal model program. A central project is the study of functorial compactifications of moduli spaces of K3 surfaces and their explicit combinatorial description. The investigator will also study the birational geometry of abelian six-folds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This overall subject area of this project is algebraic geometry, the study of solutions of polynomial equations using an intricate interplay between algebra, geometry, topology, analysis, and other tools. More specifically, the project involved work on a variety of projects centered around moduli (parameter) spaces and degenerations of algebraic varieties, compactifications of moduli spaces, and the connections to the Minimal Model Program. 

The main output of the project is seven papers and two PhD theses completed under the supervision by the PI. Some highlights of the results obtained in these papers include the following:

1. A uniformization of the moduli space of abelian varieties of dimension 6 by curves. For lower dimensions such parameterizations go back to the time of Riemann and Prym.

2. The record small volume 1/48,983 of an open surface of general type, down from a previous record 1/7,651. It is illustrated in Fig. 1.

3. A moduli compactification of the moduli space of K3 surfaces of degree 2 by using integral affine spheres with 24 singularities. It is illustrated in Fig. 2.

4. The discovery of a new class of "ADE surfaces" generalizing to dimension two of the Losev-Manin curves. They are illustrated in Fig. 3.
